content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see multiple fragments of adipose tissue, which is typical for a lymph node dissection in a colorectal cancer case. Within these fatty tissue fragments, there are several distinct, ovoid, basophilic (dark purple/blue) structures of varying sizes. These are morphologically consistent with lymph nodes. I can identify at least four major tissue pieces containing what appear to be lymph nodes. The task is to examine each of these nodes for evidence of metastatic cancer.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into this area because it contains a well-defined, basophilic nodule that is clearly identifiable as a lymph node. In cancer staging, it is mandatory to examine every single lymph node found in the resection specimen to determine the N stage (nodal involvement). This specific nodule is one of several that need to be assessed. I need to magnify it to look for the presence of atypical epithelial cells (metastatic adenocarcinoma), which would classify this lymph node as positive. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the edge of a lymph node on the left, adjacent to mature adipose tissue on the right. The lymph node tissue is very cellular and densely packed with lymphoid cells (the dark purple area). I do not see any definite evidence of metastatic carcinoma, such as atypical glands or nests of malignant epithelial cells, within this specific field. The appearance is more consistent with a reactive lymph node, which shows increased cellularity due to an immune response. My initial impression of this specific area is that it is a lymph node negative for metastasis, but the entire lymph node must be carefully examined at different magnifications to confirm this.
